page.title: 18Aycliffe Village-Buildings
page.content: The village is built on limestone and dates back before 700 A.D. The early buildings were mud and wattle.Present lay-out of the village is defensive medieval with narrow entrances for protection.Many of the older houses are built of stone but more recently brick has been used for a Council estate and for private homes as the village becomes a dormitory area for Newton Aycliffe,Darlington & Teesside. Although quarrying & farming have been the main forms of employment for centuries,at one time weaving was a major industry & the houses on the East side of the Green had huge lofts used as weaving sheds.The Church which was the centre of village life was cut off when the A1(now A167)was built.Stories exist about tunnels from the Church to Monks End and Aycliffe House,now the site of South Grove.
